title: 109_hr6291
content:
The "Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Stimulus Act of 2006" includes extensions and expansions of tax incentives for renewable energy. Section 45(d) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend the credit for electricity produced from certain renewable resources from 2008 to 2011. Additionally, the Act extends and expands the credit for holders of clean renewable energy bonds. The "Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Stimulus Act of 2006" extends tax incentives for renewable energy, including clean renewable energy bonds. Section 54 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend the national clean renewable energy bond limitation to $800,000,000 for bonds issued between 2007 and 2010. The amendments extend the national clean renewable energy bond limitation to $800,000,000 for bonds issued after the enactment of the Act. Subtitle B--Conservation and Energy Efficiency Provisions

SEC. 111. EXTENSION OF ENERGY EFFICIENT COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS DEDUCTION: Amends Section 179D(h) of the Internal Revenue Code to extend the deduction from 2007 to 2010.

SEC. 112. EXTENSION OF NEW ENERGY EFFICIENT HOME CREDIT. SEC. 112 extends the new energy efficient home credit to homes meeting specific energy saving requirements acquired after certain dates. SEC. 113 extends the residential energy efficient property credit until 2010, while SEC. 114 extends the business solar investment tax credit until 2011. SEC. 121 extends excise tax provisions and income tax credit for biodiesel and alternative fuels. SEC. 121 extends excise tax provisions and income tax credit for biodiesel and alternative fuels until 2010. Title II of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a special rule for certain alternative motor vehicles and qualified electric vehicles, exempting them from certain limitations. Additionally, there is a conforming amendment related to the Internal Revenue Code. These amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Energy will establish a program to assist States in providing consultations on weatherization and energy efficiency for residences and small businesses. States will offer information and recommendations for improving energy efficiency, but will not provide equipment or labor. States eligible for assistance are those receiving funding under the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981. Residential consultations will be available for households with incomes not exceeding 200 percent of the State median income for households of the same size. For the purposes of a program to assist States in providing consultations on weatherization and energy efficiency for residences and small businesses, the term "small businesses" refers to small business concerns as defined in the Small Business Act. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of Energy is set at $200,000,000 annually from 2007 to 2011.
